item.title: Ched Evans rape conviction quashed
item.description: Footballer Ched Evans has his conviction for rape quashed at the Court of Appeal in London, but will face a new trial.

item.title: Singer's stalker 'needs help, not jail'
item.description: A man who stalked singer Lily Allen for seven years "needs help, not jail", according to his family.

item.title: Glasgow's Blair announces retirement
item.description: Former Lions and Scotland scrum-half Mike Blair is to retire at the end of the current season with Glasgow Warriors.

item.title: Retail sales fall 1.3% in March
item.description: Retail sales volumes fell 1.3% last month compared with February, official figures show, but were 2.7% higher than a year earlier.

item.title: Row over how MoD met 2% spending target
item.description: The government faces claims it has only met the 2% Nato target on defence spending by including items such as intelligence gathering and war pensions.

item.title: Chancellor misses borrowing target
item.description: The Government borrows £74bn in the year to March, £1.8bn more than George Osborne's borrowing target.

item.title: Victoria Wood remembered at Funny Girl
item.description: One funny girl paid tribute to another on Wednesday as Sheridan Smith took time out from a glitzy West End opening to remember Victoria Wood.

item.title: Race to ratify the Paris climate deal
item.description: The first significant step to putting the Paris Climate Agreement into practice will take place at the UN on Friday when over 150 nations are expected to formally sign the deal.

item.title: Ladbrokes: Cheltenham 'worst in memory'
item.description: Bookmaker Ladbrokes says this year's Cheltenham Festival was its "worst in living memory" and confirms it will pay out £3m if Leicester win the Premier League.

item.title: Queen has been 'rock of strength' - PM
item.description: The Queen has been "a rock of strength for our nation" and the Commonwealth, says Prime Minister David Cameron ahead of events on the day of her 90th birthday.

item.title: Mitsubishi Motors office raided
item.description: Japanese officials raid an office of Mitsubishi Motors following the revelation on Wednesday that it had falsified fuel economy data.

item.title: Can even FA Cup save 'hapless' Martinez?
item.description: After Everton's 4-0 thrashing in the Merseyside derby on Wednesday, is Roberto Martinez's future at Goodison Park all but sealed?

item.title: Money laundering targeted by new plans
item.description: MPs, councillors and civil servants suspected of corruption are to be targeted as part of anti-money laundering measures proposed by Home Secretary Theresa May.

item.title: 'I'll sprint down The Mall like Bolt'
item.description: Spinal injections, 5am alarm calls and a body in "shock" - Dame Kelly Holmes on her quest to finish the London Marathon.

item.title: Adele 'richest ever UK female musician'
item.description: Adele has been named as Britain's richest ever female musician, according to the annual music rich list compiled by Sunday Times.

item.title: The Queen at 90 and Victoria Wood tributes
item.description: Thursday's headlines are dominated by the Queen's birthday and the death of comedian Victoria Wood.

item.title: NHS to give GP services extra £2.4bn
item.description: A major five-year investment in general practice in England is announced, with NHS bosses promising to "pull out all the stops" to help GP surgeries "get back on their feet".

item.title: Panama Papers and Pakistan PM Nawaz Sharif
item.description: The family of Pakistan Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif were among those revealed in the Panama Papers to have offshore firms. The BBC's M Ilyas Khan looks at the fall-out of the revelations.

item.title: In pictures: Lives changed by Nepal quake
item.description: Four young people injured in the earthquake that struck Nepal in April 2015 rebuild their lives.

item.title: What's the difference between a stalker and a super-fan?
item.description: What goes on in the mind of fans who pester their hero?

item.title: How the French learned to love their police
item.description: How the French learned to love their police

item.title: William Shakespeare's economic legacy
item.description: Shakespeare’s lessons for today’s business leaders

item.title: VIDEO: Hillary's hot sauce claim inflames 'pandering' row
item.description: Was Clinton's foodie confession a bid to win over black voters?

item.title: What is 'actual innocence' in US justice?
item.description: Could a radical experiment save the broken US justice system?

item.title: 'More action taken' on child abuse images
item.description: Nearly 70,000 examples of online content showing child sex abuse have been removed from the internet in the past year, the UK charity leading the efforts to combat the abuse says.

item.title: Martinez 'embarrassed' by derby defeat
item.description: Everton boss Roberto Martinez says he was "embarrassed" by the 4-0 defeat at Liverpool, describing it as his worst moment at the club.

item.title: 2.2 billion in 'at risk' Zika areas
item.description: More than two billion people live in parts of the world where the Zika virus can spread, detailed maps show.

item.title: VIDEO: Key moments of the Queen's reign
item.description: The Queen is celebrating her 90th birthday. The BBC's Victoria Derbyshire programme looks back at key moments in her reign.

item.title: Sats spelling test was on practice paper
item.description: A Sats spelling test due to be taken by half a million seven-year-olds in England in two weeks' time was accidentally published as a sample test months ago, it has emerged.

item.title: Comedian Victoria Wood dies aged 62
item.description: Comedian Victoria Wood has died after a "short but brave" battle with cancer, her publicist says.

item.title: Leaving EU 'will save tens of billions'
item.description: The UK will make huge savings from exiting the EU, a Leave campaigner says as he likens "conventional wisdom" in favour of membership with appeasement of Hitler in the 1930s.

item.title: Blouse-ripping sex scene brings down Australian MP
item.description: Raunchy sex scene sinks Australian politician

item.title: Microsoft discontinues Xbox 360 console
item.description: Microsoft says it is to stop manufacturing the Xbox 360 games console, 10 years after it launched.

item.title: Chameleon's tongue gives up secrets
item.description: Scientists build a mathematical model that explains the secrets of the chameleon's extraordinary tongue.

item.title: Academy accounts uncertain, says watchdog
item.description: The Department for Education is severely reprimanded by the National Audit Office for failing to properly account for spending by academies.

item.title: PM vows to 'finish the job' on academies
item.description: David Cameron defends controversial plans to force all state schools in England to become academies, saying it is time to "finish the job".

item.title: VIDEO: 'Islamic State's' most wanted - Part 1: The takeover
item.description: What happens when you resist the world's most violent jihadis?

item.title: Lily Allen on stalking terror and speaking out
item.description: Singer Lily Allen on why she spoke out

item.title: Boy born to brain-dead mother goes home
item.description: A baby boy has now gone home safe and well after his brain-dead mother was kept alive on life support so he could be born, Polish authorities say.

item.title: VIDEO: Race car narrowly avoids hitting deer
item.description: A deer in Poland had a lucky escape when it narrowly missed being hit by a racing car.

item.title: Final decision on 'no A-level borough'
item.description: Governors in a Knowsley academy are to make a final decision on whether to close a sixth form which would mean an entire borough would have no schools with A-level places.

item.title: Early Attenborough to screen in colour
item.description: Sir David Attenborough's early natural history films are to be be shown in colour for the first time to mark the broadcaster's 90th birthday.

item.title: The strange way people looked at food in the 16th Century
item.description: It may seem a peculiarly 21st Century preoccupation, but people in Shakespeare's England were also obsessed with food, writes Dr Joan Fitzpatrick.

item.title: Help! My building has been hacked
item.description: There are millions of buildings being connected to the net, which makes them vulnerable to cyber-attack, so should we be worried?

item.title: How four men survived as hostages of IS
item.description: At one point in 2013-2014 IS held 19 men hostage in one room. Here four of them explain how they helped each other through the ordeal.

item.title: In pictures: Queen at 90 in 90 images
item.description: An image from every year of Elizabeth II's life

item.title: Chicago cop charged with murder in killing of black teen
item.description: Daniel Q. Herbert, attorney for the Chicago police officer who fatally shot Laquan McDonald holds a new conference at the Law Offices of Daniel Q. Herbert & Associates in Chicago on Friday, Nov. 20, 2015. CHICAGO- A white Chicago police officer accused of fatally shooting a black teenager was charged with murder Tuesday, just a day ahead of a deadline for the city to release a squad-car video of the killing.

item.title: Quinnipiac Poll: Ted Cruz on fire in Iowa tied with Donald Trump; Carson sliding
item.description: If Trump wants the government to act on his proposal, he might have overlooked one roadblock: the U.S. Constitution. The big news out of Iowa Tuesday morning is that Texas U.S. Senator Ted Cruz is starting to catch fire in Iowa, a sure indication that the race for the Republican nomination is wide open, according to a newly-released Quinnipiac University poll .

item.title: US governor faces lawsuit for blocking Syrian refugees
item.description: " The governor of Midwestern Indiana state is being sued over his decision to block Syrian refugees from resettling in the state. The lawsuit comes about a week after Gov. Mike Pence objected to plans for refugees to arrive in Indiana following the deadly attacks in Paris.

item.title: Lehigh University: Student, 2 men charged with hate crime
item.description: Officials say a Lehigh University student and two other men are charged with a hate crime for saying an anti-gay slur and pushing another student to the ground. Police say the victim and another man were approached by three men and an anti-gay slur was uttered before the argument turned into a fight.
